ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to develop a lengthy historical paper from extensive archival source research
Historical and Archival research!
working independently, using archives, immersing in a content area, revising writing
I gained so much through this experience including how to synthesize large amounts of research and how to work on an extended project.
How to do "real history," i.e. writing a journal article

I was able to design and complete a long-term research project that required substantive archival research in multiple languages. I am now much more confident in employing these skills to undertake similar projects in the future.

I developed my research and writing skills, especially for a year-long project of this magnitude. I especially learned how to analyze primary and secondary sources, and how to use these sources to support an argument that was much larger than anything I have previously done in smaller papers.

In writing my senior essay, I honed my research, critical thinking, writing, editing, and storytelling skills. I feel prepared to undertake vast research projects that require long-term time management skills.
Writing a year-long research paper was an incredibly valuable experience that honed my skills in time-management, independent research, and managing a long-term project.
This class was an excellent opportunity to engage in research, and I learned a lot about how to do so in an efficient manner.
I learned all about how to write a work of serious historical scholarship, from finding a topic, doing primary and secondary research, then writing and editing so much.

Through writing my senior essay, I really got a grip of what it is like to take on a massive project myself. I learned more about constructing arguments, finding sources, and the difficulty of just writing. But through it I really honed my academic skills.
Writing a big amount

I learned a lot from my advisor. He was amazing. Every other aspect of this was terrible. The history thesis system, more so than any other major at Yale, needs a gigantic overhaul. It is unfulfilling and graded to ridiculous scrutiny. Completely subjective if you get a grader that wants to destroy you or grades to PhD level standard. This experience made me not want to continue pursuing history in any other capacity other than picking up a book from time to time.
How to plan and follow through on a large-scale, year long research project

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths - my advisor, Yale's collections, funding availability
weaknesses - communication from History department is unpredictable (emails will say different things than the handbook, administrators might misplace forms, etc.)

Your experience and how you structure workload is very dependent on your advisor. Some of the milestone assignments are not especially helpful, but the annotated bibliography, ten page draft and rough draft were all helpful for my process. Also, the grading can be a bit inconsistent as it depends heavily on which faculty member reads your essay.

One's success in the course is very much contingent upon one's relationship with their advisor. I had a very good relationship with my advisor who was able to synthesize competing strands of thought and recommend appropriate courses of action.

Strengths:
- I like the milestone assignments throughout the year and each semester that kept me one track and working towards the final project, so that it didn't all hit me at once
- It's super exciting to be able to pick a topic of your own interest and have the freedom and independence to lead a research project on it, and see it come together over the course of a year!

Weaknesses:
- Opportunities to gain feedback on your work are variable and very dependent on your personal advisor. I would have appreciated more opportunities to get help and feedback on my work throughout the process

The history senior thesis has clear expectations, assignments, and timelines. Although one's experience writing it will inherently be influenced by their advisor  and I had the BEST advisor  the course is designed for students to succeed in writing a strong paper.

I would have liked to receive more personal feedback from my instructor on the course of my paper.

The way the timeline of the paper was organized was great for getting work done ahead of schedule. I liked the level of freedom and sense of self direction that was a part of the paper-writing process, but I know others requested more direction.

I loved how independent it was, which let me go at my own pace and do the work whenever I wanted and as quickly as I could. I also really loved being able to fully pick my own topic. I think most of the small assignments are silly and that's a weakness but I do wish we had a little more checkins with advisors that were substantive.
The deadlines for milestones are too early and dont make sense

The quality of advising could really be improved. Up until the point where I submitted a full rough draft, I received essentially zero feedback from my advisor. I tried multiple times to meet with him and talked about my thoughts and ideas, but I received very little engagement or guidance on the part of my professor.

I think the History department could support individual advisors better (clearly let them know deadlines, give them basic expectations/guides etc.), which would in turn help them support their students.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The senior thesis is an incredibly fulfilling project. It seems really intimidating when you first start, but by the end you will look back and be incredibly proud of your hard work and your achievement.
Yes, I gained valuable skills through my research and writing of the essay, and discovered more about my writing style and way of processing information through the project.
YES! but I had a fantastic advisor who I met with regularly
you gotta do it
Yes! A great end to the history thesis, and the 2 semester project allows you more time to delve deeper into a topic of your interest, as well as make the finial project stronger
History majors do not have a choice but to take this course, but I nonetheless strongly recommend writing a senior thesis!
It is a lot of work, but if you enjoy research and putting together a compelling narrative, you will enjoy the process.
Yes I would recommend the year-long since a one semester project is basically a term paper. It's pretty fun to do your own thing all year.

All history majors have to do it, but I definitely believe doing a two semester is the right option. It also really is a product of what you put into it. The more you work and the more you really care about what you are writing about, the better time you will have.
It's mandatory, so

absolutely not. Please switch majors. This thesis process has to be the worst at Yale. The advisors are wonderful but you can have your advisor think your paper is a work of art and get a grader that will give you a B-. Seriously. For two semesters. Not to say everyone should care about their GPA like that (because they shouldn't!), but that's a wonderful gift while all my friends in other majors write their thesis overnight and their advisor grades it as an A, meanwhile, I spend an entire year diligently working on something with multiple drafts sent to my advisor, writing tutors, and peers and then some historian completely rips it apart. If I could go back, I'd become an American Studies or Humanities or Poli Sci major. It's unfair that the history department does things differently from other disciplines. Why? 

A committee of professors or your advisor should grade the thesis!!! Not one other professor, and then that grade is final! That is such a horrible system. There are so many differing viewpoints in the department. My grader thought my paper was bad, and my advisor thought it was amazing (independent from hurting my feeling). What an amazing way to feel like you've wasted a year of your life when a professor says you wrote sloppily. Please fix this for other students. I've never written a course review like this... I think this process is simply in desperate need of an overhaul. Listen to the students! They feel awful about this process. They are scared the entire time they are writing their thesis! We are undergraduates, not PhD students. People get nominated for the history essay awards with not amazing thesis grades. That's so crazy.
